newsitem.title: FRANCE: Prodi says Europe weaker without Italy.
newsitem.headline: Prodi says Europe weaker without Italy.

text.p: Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi said in a newspaper interview on Thursday that a Europe without Italy would be weakened.
"I am convinced that the future of Italy is with Europe," he said in an interview with daily Le Figaro.
"I am also convinced that without Italy Europe would be weakened, continually submitted to trade turbulence and serious political problems," he said.
"Italy is the leading edge of Mediterranean Europe. Everybody, beginning with France, needs a stable and united Italy," he added.

Prodi said it would be unrealistic to change the Maastricht treaty terms on European Economic and Monetary Union and reaffirmed a denial that he had sought to convince Spain to help Italy soften the criteria.
"That idea never entered my head," he said in the interview. "I think it would be unrealistic to change the Maastricht rules, whether they are good or bad."

"Many other measures could have been taken into account. Notably efforts achieved by different countries to meet convergence criteria. But I believe that the treaty is sacred and must be respected," he added.
